title: What is the concept behind the graph in E. Dacqué's work on the evolution of human beings?
first_phrase: In the preceding text, the author discusses the concept of "conquest" as the attainment of a physical state of existence in conditions known to us, where humans are the only ones who have succeeded in this conquest while others have deviated or branched out into different directions. The author describes how the human form is a result of a primordial humanity in which various animal species were included. In the last 200 tokens, the author references the works of E. Dacqué to support their ideas and includes a graphical representation to illustrate the concept further. The graph shows that humans as we know them today are located in the direction where the central line ends, while other attempts, such as the prehistoric man, the anthropoid, and the man-ape, can be considered closer attempts. The earlier and more divergent attempts can be found further back in time and are accessible through paleontology.

last_phrase: In conclusion, it's interesting to note that these ideas have also emerged on the fringes of modern culture, without a connection to traditional teaching. Understanding this concept can be challenging, but the graphic provided by E. Dacqué clarifies it well. It's essential to acknowledge that the transition from one species to another doesn't occur at the periphery, but rather through various transformations, adaptations, and selections. Darwin's theory of factors explains this process, and it's essential to consider these factors when analyzing the evolution of species.
